title: COVID-19 Vaccination in Nigeria
description: This post contains simple overview of the COVID-19 statistics in Nigeria and the vaccination statistics up till August, 2021.
contents:
Contents
Introduction
Data Description
COVID-19 Confirmed cases and Death
Vaccine Source and Vaccination Rate

Data Exploration




Introduction
As we move towards the third quarter of 2021, many countries around the world have been accelerating their vaccination process. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for other countries, especially those developing countries without the technology or resource to develop their own vaccines. Nigeria, being a country under the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP), is one of the countries that requires external support. In this blog post, I will be looking into the coronavirus situation in Nigeria using data from Our World in Data.
Data Description
Two data sets are used in this short overview of COVID-19 situation in Nigeria, one on COVID-19 cases and one regarding the vaccination progress in Nigeria Hannah Ritchie and Roser (2020).
COVID-19 Confirmed cases and Death
Due to the conditions in Nigeria, many of the more detailed variables such as icu patients, weekly_icu_admissions..etc. are missing from the data set. As COVID-19 related data is aggregated for countries all around the world, more developed countries with better recording resources will have more data. Nigeria, on the other hand, lacks record hence it has 45 less columns of data in comparison. For the purpose of my analysis, I cleaned up the data to remove the columns with completely no data, and used the remaining columns to illustrate the conditions of Nigeria.



Following is the data description table for the cases data set:



Table 1: Data Description table for COVID-19 Confirmed cases and Death


Variables


Description


date


Date of Record


total_cases


Total confirmed cases of COVID-19


new_cases


New confirmed cases of COVID-19


new_cases_smoothed


New confirmed cases of COVID-19 (7-day smoothed)


total_deaths


Total deaths attributed to COVID-19


new_deaths


New deaths attributed to COVID-19


new_deaths_smoothed


New deaths attributed to COVID-19 (7-day smoothed)


total_cases_per_million


Total confirmed cases of COVID-19 per 1,000,000 people


new_cases_per_million


New confirmed cases of COVID-19 per 1,000,000 people


new_cases_smoothed_per_million


New confirmed cases of COVID-19 (7-day smoothed) per 1,000,000 people


total_deaths_per_million


Total deaths attributed to COVID-19 per 1,000,000 people


new_deaths_per_million


New deaths attributed to COVID-19 per 1,000,000 people


new_deaths_smoothed_per_million


New deaths attributed to COVID-19 (7-day smoothed) per 1,000,000 people


reproduction_rate


Real-time estimate of the effective reproduction rate (R) of COVID-19



Vaccine Source and Vaccination Rate
Our World in Data’s vaccination data is a compilation of vaccination data that are verifiable based on public official sources. The vaccination data is separated into two smaller data set, one containing the source of the vaccines and the other the vaccinated population count.
Vaccine Source
The following table contains the data descriptions for the vaccine source:





Table 2: Data Description table for vaccine source


Variables


Description


Pipeline


The vaccine pipeline through which the vaccine was delivered. Either COVAX or Other.


Vaccine


The common name of the vaccine delivered


Funder


The name of the funder that funded the procurement of the vaccine. ‘Procured’ is used where a country purchased the vaccines using their own funds.


Doses


The number of doses delivered


Source.Url


The URL of the source article where information about the delivery was published


NewPipeline


Combination of pipeline and Funder


Date


The date when the vaccine delivery was reported


Vaccine Administered
The following table contains the data descriptions for the vaccination progress:






Table 3: Data Description table for the vaccination progress


Variables


Description


date


Date of the observation


total_vaccinations


Total number of doses administered. For vaccines that require multiple doses, each individual dose is counted. If a person receives one dose of the vaccine, this metric goes up by 1. If they receive a second dose, it goes up by 1 again. If they receive a third/booster dose, it goes up by 1 again.


people_vaccinated


total number of people who received at least one vaccine dose. If a person receives the first dose of a 2-dose vaccine, this metric goes up by 1. If they receive the second dose, the metric stays the same.


people_fully_vaccinated


Total number of people who received all doses prescribed by the vaccination protocol. If a person receives the first dose of a 2-dose vaccine, this metric stays the same. If they receive the second dose, the metric goes up by 1.


daily_vaccinations_raw


Daily change in the total number of doses administered. It is only calculated for consecutive days.


daily_vaccinations


New doses administered per day (7-day smoothed). For countries that don’t report data on a daily basis, we assume that doses changed equally on a daily basis over any periods in which no data was reported. This produces a complete series of daily figures, which is then averaged over a rolling 7-day window.


total_vaccinations_per_hundred


total_vaccinations per 100 people in the total population of the country.


people_vaccinated_per_hundred


people_vaccinated per 100 people in the total population of the country.


people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred


people_fully_vaccinated per 100 people in the total population of the country.


daily_vaccinations_per_million


daily_vaccinations per 1,000,000 people in the total population of the country.



Data Exploration
Cases and Deaths
The table below is an interactive table that explores the confirmed cases and COVID-19 related deaths in Nigeria since the first outbreak in February of 2020.
It is important to note that because there were only two dates recorded for cases in February 2020, the monthly cases plot is unreliable. The mean reproduction rate of the virus was calculated for each month by taking the average. Days were the reproduction rate was not recorded are not included in the computation.

type, row, meta) {\n    return type !== 'display' ? data : DTWidget.formatRound(data, 3, 3, \",\", \".\");\n  }"},{"className":"dt-right","targets":[4,5,6,7,8]},{"orderable":false,"targets":0}],"order":[],"autoWidth":false,"orderClasses":false,"orderCellsTop":true}},"evals":["options.columnDefs.0.render"],"jsHooks":[]}
Figure 1: Confrimed Cases and Deaths from 2020-2021



Table 1 shows that a month with high number of new cases is followed by a month with high death. For example January 2021, where the highest number of new cases was recorded in a month, was followed by February, with the highest record of deaths in a month. A reason for the surge of second wave in January 2021 was explained in this Financial Times article.

“What is driving it . . . is very clearly human behaviour,” he said, arguing that, after strong compliance with mitigation measures last year, “prevention fatigue” had set in, with people neglecting social distancing practices. Neil Munshi and Schipani (2021)

Since then, measures has been taken to enhance regulations. “President Muhammadu Buhari signed the COVID-19 Health Protection Regulations into law in January 2021” Oghifo (2021).
Vaccines
With people getting tired of social distancing practices, the next best way to fight against the virus is vaccines. However, Nigeria is slow at vaccinating its people. This is largely due to the lack of access to the vaccines.
The following is a table of all the vaccines Nigeria has received

4000080


As shown in the table above, almost all of the vaccines Nigeria received has was from other countries. They only government bought vaccines were 300000 doses of Astra Zeneca. It is clear that Nigeria is in a passive position when it comes to vaccination.

Figure 2: Daily Vaccination record of 2021



At first glance, it may seem like Nigeria has vaccinated a lot of it’s people. However, Considering that Nigeria has a population of 201 million people, this vaccination rate is quite low.
